commentBody: I liked having to think about the big clues, but it was a little to easy to fill in the downs to get them.
19A is dedicated to Mean Old Lady.

JACKIE ROBINSON seems a tad too close to Jack of diamonds, even "in support of a theme."

IMO

Pretty easy for a Thursday.  I got MASTERGARDNER without seeing the gimmick, but caught on at TIGERWOODS.  After that it was smooth sailing.  I would have appreciated the theme a little more if all the answers had been real people, or, conversely, if they’d all been categories of people.

Since you asked, I have never in my life hard of Millionaire Matchmaker nor Patti Stanger.

'Race' is very commonly used for non-human living things. Often to mean 'subspecies' but more commonly to indicate a level below even subpecies. But sometimes used to indicate any related group of things.
Tsar Nicholas II abdicated in March 1917. The USSR did not exist until 1922.

Either I'm getting better or the puzzles are getting easier. I lean toward the latter. Yesterday was my fastest Wednesday puzzle ever. Today is my fastest Thursday puzzle -- even faster than yesterday. I'm expecting a monstrously difficult puzzle upcoming.

Nice theme. Got a little messed up with MEKONG/MAC/ACCEDE. I had pAl in there for a while, and pEKONG seemed okay to me.  AlCEDE looked wrong, but couldn't think of ACCEDE.

After double checking, pEKONG and AlCEDE were my lowest degrees of certainty, so I tried to think of a word that would work instead of pAl. Remembered MAC from a previous crossword, and that got me the gold star

I'd call this a fine Tuesday puzzle.
Perfectly pleasant, but little challenge and no trick.

Me: “I think it’s time to renovate the strawberry area this year.”
Best beloved: “Do you want to move them back to where they were before?”
Me: “Nope.”

This is the first I've ever heard of the entirety of dinosaurs called a "race".

I think of "race" as a particularly human concept.  

Moreover members of different races have a lot more in common with each other than Compsognathus had with Spinosaurus. 

I liked the theme, and internally chuckled when it showed itself.  

But the fit between the clues an the answers seemed a little looser than usual.  For example:  GONE for [Blotto] seemed a little tenuous.

Emily and Sala, thank you for this painless Thursday.  Clever fills for the theme clues, and a welcome absence of screechy skews to make the crosses work.  Lots of smiles while I was solving—I especially liked the punctuation.

I hope we'll see another puzzle from you soon. Any day is okay with me.
Either NYT has dialed back the difficulty, or I’m getting better at these things.

So, three things:
1) WHY NOT have a column picture that INCLUDES a hecklefon? We’ve got a bass clarinet and a contrabassoon in there. Yeesh!
2) A “youth” explained to me years ago that “no cap” means honest, as opposed to wearing a baseball cap to hide one’s baldness, so really unrelated to ‘cap’ as slang for “lie” in an older sense — but how reliable are “youths” (or “utes”)?
3) using the word “species” to categorize dinosaurs is more nonsensical than “race.” Are dinosaurs an order, like mammals? A subgroup of reptiles, at the family level? I don’t think there’s a good answer that leaves us with a joke clue.

Just needed the DINOSAURS hint to get past the fact I put ACES instead of ONES for rare golf scores. Otherwise I found this puzzle enjoyable and breezy, but not without some head scratching along the way here and there.
I loved seeing JACKIE ROBINSON.  I grew up as a Brooklyn Dodger fan.  I think I still am although they deserted me.

Another day of having difficulties, only to find that absolutely no one else had even the tiniest problem with it.

I gotta learn some Pixar film names.  And learn some actors from the 21st century.  And NBA stars.

This one was actually an easy solve for me. Pretty straight-forward Thursday. The card puns were really fun!
Dinosaurs are still around. Birds are literally dinosaurs. It was a tad disappointing to see this common misunderstanding make its way into the crossword.

For once we had a more classic rebus. I was confused by it for a long time, but then things clicked into place. Strangely, the first themed entry I got was JACKIE ROBINSON (via crosses and educated guesses), even though I had no idea who that might be 🤣 (*of course*! A baseball player! Thanks, Google).

Is the column right about the Corner:TREE thing? Can "tree" actually be a verb? That's some of the most arcane stuff I've ever seen in these puzzles. 

The clueing was not really on my wavelength, so I ended up looking up several things (CUBS, MOON DANCE, D-LIST) to generate much needed crosses. Other unknows I got through crosses only, like ELIO and MANU (the only sporting Manu I am familiar with is the French climber Cornu).

Remembering the name ERIVO and things like BTU and E-CIG from previous puzzles was a big help. NO CAP, too.

Overall I mostly enjoyed the puzzle.

As a septuagenarian who doesn't watch television, I sometimes struggle with modern cultural and social references.  No, I don't live in a cave, but pop culture can stump me at times.  I'm grateful to Wordplay for helping out with the more obscure clues and answers.  Keep up the great work!
On the first pass, I put “PrincessDi” for Q♥️, mostly for SENTIMENTAL reasons. I knew it would not last (*sigh*). Good puzzle.
Fun to have a Thursday puzzle that doesn't involve intentional misspellings.

I reckon the NYT crossword is an under-appreciated trivia educational aid. It enables Brits to learn American culture (i now know more about SSNs than I’d ever care to imagine), old fogeys to keep up with the youth speak (what on earth is NOCAP? This is the only way we’d ever hear about it) and everyone can argue about etymology (OCTOPI…. There, I said it!)

P.s. my favourite etymological nitpick: “helicopter” is not heli+copter but helico (screw) + pter (wing). I hope that was uplifting for y’all!

yeah, im sorry.

and if JACK of diamonds is going to result in JACK/JACKIE as a proper name in the solve, then the other rebi should be so structured.

i just found the device too contrived by half and the overall difficulty at the level of a tuesday.

I LOVED Millionaire Matchmaker (got hooked when a Top Chef contestant, or “cheftestant,” appeared in an episode) and would have been thrilled to see the most unlikely of my hobbies intersect - mindless reality TV and NYT crossword puzzles! But I think Sala’s instincts were right. It’s a pretty niche reference, especially since the show’s original run ended almost a decade ago. And good thing, because this was an endlessly charming grid from start to finish. Save me a stool at the Painted Lady to watch Patti if she ever returns to Bravo, though!

To answer the constructors's question - I never heard of Millionaire Matchmaker and Patty Stanger.  And it's not something I would ever watch, if I had run across it.

Tiger Woods, on the other hand, I have heard of, and have watched in person twice.  So he was my clue into the puzzle theme.  I also know some master gardeners.  Jackie Robinson's number is retired by every MLB team, and was another easy answer.

I can’t remember the last time I disliked a puzzle more. Millionaire Matchmaker? Cutesy rebuses? Another Bravo show? Names like Erivo from another TV show? Not a single interesting fact to be gleaned from the entire puzzle, and on top of that it wasn’t exactly challenging, only gimicky. 

10 minutes I’ll never get back. 

What I would like to ask of the NYT is that the next time a constructor tells you they were “inspired” by a Bravo show, hold out for one who was inspired by literature or science or music.

By the way, the heckelphone – which has appeared at least ten times in NYT clues – resembles an oboe, but is pitched an octave lower and is about twice as long.  Only about 150 have been made (it was introduced in 1904), and about 100 still exist. It was invented by, a person whose last name was, of course, Heckel.  It is heavy enough to where it needs to rest on the floor, supported by a metal peg at its bottom.  (Thank you Wikipedia.)

I think it would be the perfect instrument for making bleating sounds to protest bad jokes made by a comedian at a live performance.

Not what I look forward to from a Thursday. 

There was no great mystery to be solved in the theme clues. Could just as easily have been spelled out I.e. “King of Clubs”, etc. 

And DINOSAUR is not a race. Race isn’t a biological reality, it’s a social construct, and it most definitely is not a synonym for “species”. Pretty poor, honestly. Wrong on multiple levels. 

I don’t like to be negative about puzzles because I appreciate the time and effort that go into making them but this was a Wednesday at best.

Since SCION is a relatively new word in my vocabulary -- I've never used it in speaking or writing -- for several minutes it prevented me from getting the unknown ELIO.  The NW was another area that did not go as smoothly as the rest of the puzzle.  Even so, completed it in 10% less time than average.  

I like that all the suits were covered in the four top playing cards that comprised the theme clues.

Will I be the ten-dozenth to ask if the "clue" for 57A violates the rule that the clue should not include part of the entry?  
I do see that the constructors didn't want to declare two Kings, but.....There are, after all, four Kings in every deck.

DINOSAURS were hardly "a race," especially if you differentiate among lizard-hipped and bird-hipped species.  Careless clue?
(I also question the 39D clue/entry pair...lack of parallelism?)

Nice to see a shout out for master gardeners!  If you’re not aware of it, each state (and several provinces in Canada) have a wonderful and totally free master gardener volunteer program to answer all your home gardening questions.  In the U.S. it is funded by the land grant/cooperative extension program and nearly every county in the has this program.  

The “Master Gardener” volunteer help-line is a wonderful and free resource is staffed by highly trained volunteers.   If you have gardening questions or problems, you can call, email, or even just pop in!

(At the 4:39 mark) https://youtu.be/sfTbebGq53M?si=AXlpUsmf12rxFp5b Thank you so very much for the visual of grannie's podiatric maladies. Quick… think of Salma Hayek! Ahh, much better. Sibyls and blotto really threw me off a fairly smooth solve. I have been blotto just a time or two and Sally Fields did give a masterful performance, but those clues would have been too elementary for the likes of the NYT solvers. I struggle with b-u being anything other than a measurement of heat. Maybe because of the reference to "thermal," as in a winter undergarment. I do give the British a pass though for their Navel Connectors. I've always used them on my speakers, in those bygone days before Bluetooth. Yaki Mandu rolls off the tongue so much better than does --on, too bad I couldn't squeeze it in. Grrr. I'll try ordering it as my next bento box. I wanted 65A to be TART so badly, but it's like mini vs. midi or tsar vs. czar... almost. Tarts and tangs certainly are not bygone rulers. No cap.

Stymied for a while by two stubborn wrong answers that I couldn't unsee: "cobra" (1D) jumped out and bit me right off the bat (aren't they curved?), and "sic--cbd" (40A=41D) were oh-so-obvious. Confusion ensued...Curses!  (or just "CMON, guys!")

I salute all crossword constructors.  I can't imagine the amount of work they put in, or the amount of rejection they have to deal with, just to see their name in the Times.  Or the stupid comments they have to see.

That being said, I look forward to Thursday puzzles all week, and this was a disappointing Thursday.
It's easy to explain why.
The gimmick is cute, but it takes less than a half-second to figure it out.  Anyone who has played cards automatically says the card name to themself when they see it written out in the manner of these clues.  
I love Jackie Robinson, but cluing his name as "Jack of Diamonds" would be unacceptable on a Monday, let alone a Thursday, because part of the answer is in the clue!  But that's what most solvers will say to themselves when they see J[Diamond].

Now that I've got that off my chest, I'll add that "King of Clubs" is a nice clue for TIGER WOODS, and "Ace of Spades" is excellent for MASTER GARDENER.
But it's Monday/Tuesday good.  
I expect more on a Thursday.
Congrats on your second NYT puzzle Emily and Sala, well done my dears.

I have nothing but respect for anyone who gets a puzzle published in the Times.  It's hard for me to even imagine the amount of work -- or the amount of rejection -- that goes into getting one accepted.  And that doesn't even account for having to deal with us idiots and our annoying comments!
That having been said, as someone who looks forward to Thursdays all week, I have to agree with so many people here and say that this was a disappointing Thursday puzzle.   It's fairly easy to explain why.  If the clues had been spelled out -- that is "Queen of Hearts" instead of Q[Heart], there is no gimmick, just clues that are cards.  But everyone who has any experience playing cards automatically says to themself "Queen of Hearts" when they see that symbol.
And I love Jackie Robinson, but cluing his name as "Jack of Diamonds" would be unacceptable even on a Monday, since part of the answer is in the clue.  So, why should J[Diamond] be acceptable.
On the other hand there is some nice cluing here.  "King of Clubs" is a fine clue for TIGER WOODS, and "Ace of spades" is excellent for MASTER GARDENER.
But it's Monday/Tuesday level good.
Not good enough for a Thursday.

Thanks  Emily Biegas and Sala Wanetick for your efforts.  Sorry that your puzzle got printed on the wrong day and now you have to deal with us idiots.

@Jon

I get very tired of this argument. 

Yes, there is probably a genetic link between the dinosaurs and birds.

BUT, c'mon man!  It's quite obvious that the differences are so great now vs. 100 million years ago as to make that link essentially meaningless in terms of describing the animals that now exist.

It's like saying the US midwest is essentially in inland sea, because it was at the time of the dinosaurs.

@Jon

I know.  But dinosaurs and birds are not the same in the common imagination and language as they are for paleontologists.  So immediately we have a clash between what humans think when they think of dinosaurs and what they think when they think of birds.  Those two things are very, very different.

But you do make me wonder something:  how close are some of the dinosaur fossils to modern bird bone structure?  Were there essentially canaries in the Cretaceous?  Parrots?  Peacocks? Emus?

I don't know the answer.  I'd be surprised if it was yes, but not flabbergasted.

😀

All I'm really trying to say is that the biological differences between what we think of as dinosaurs and birds is so enormous that they really defy comparison, regardless of the evolutionary path.

@Stephen

Yeah, I think it's cool, too!

But that's not the point.  The point is that regardless of what the DNA says (and I love DNA) what registers in the human mind when you say "dinosaur" is vastly different from what registers in the human mind when you say "bird".

And my questions were never fully answered:

If the extinction event killed only *some* of the dinosaurs, then is there fossil evidence for ancestors of birds like we see today:  canaries, wren, blue jays, storks?  I'm not saying that if the answer is "no", that I'm right, because we may just not have found them.  I'm just asking the question.

If not, then the probability is that birds came from a tiny minority of dinosaurs, which are completely different from what you and I picture when we think "dinosaur".

Again, it comes down to how different do two things need to be to be considered different?

Are will still the common ancestor of our lemur cousins?  No, of course not.  We've changed in enormous ways from our lemur ancestry.

So have birds.

@The X-Phile

I see your point but I still don't personally like the hero label. I've been thinking about more of my reasons for that stance.

Some Polish heroes were properly nasty people, in reality. As ugly facts about them emerge, they rarely lose their popular hero status. Thus, the ugliness in their lives becomes normalized. "Hey, so and so did *this and that*, but he was a hero whose example we should all follow, so I can do *this and that*, too!"

Also, the hero label may dehumanize a person. A mythical being can't be human, can they? Thus, can a hero enjoy the dignity all humans deserve? 

Finally, and this connects to my dislike for rites and rituals, I don't need to think of a person as a hero to value their achievements and any examples they may have set. Those speak for themselves. 

(Also, I've recently realized in probably somewhere on the autism spectrum, which may be relevant here).

@Kroobey

@Francis

@Andrzej

I see your point.  We should all be sufficiently adult to realize that all heroes are humans, and all humans are flawed.  But there must be a degree of being flawed after which you can no longer be considered a hero.

I have major issues with the concept of "hero", too, especially as it is used in the super-hero sense which seems to have sucked so much oxygen out of our cultural atmosphere.  Such super-heroes have the effect of being super-human to such an extent that the message is that we mere humans can't do anything to combat the problems that we encounter. Only a "hero" can save us. This teaches complacency and inertia.  

The heroes that I admire inspire us to be the best humans we can be, and surely we often need such inspiration.

commentBody:
@Vaer

I usually don't read the constructor's notes. I'm here to solve your puzzle, not get your backstory, though I know some enjoy them.

@Cleo Its old, hasn't been on in years, a true deep cut hahah

@Christian

As far as I’m aware, the penchant of the US military for assigning card values to human targets is unique to the US. And an uncomfortably juvenile way to refer to targets for killing.

@Byron
Inasmuch as I am adverse to weighing in on topics that were meant to stir controversy, I break character here. I respect your point of view, yet I fail to recall the Royal Canadian armed forces leading the way in spearheading the removal of a dictatorship that oppressed and tortures its citizens. Nor have I seen nation building, training, or large amounts of humanitarian aid originating in Canada. I’m not going to do needless  research into the uniqueness of the US and card-based representation of enemy hostiles, but war is uncomfortable. Considering your juvenile reference, maybe it is. Soldiers don’t find humor in it, nor did many of us embrace it, but neutralizing a target is not for the weak. The countries that the US have historically liberated were on a downward spiral long before US involvement. Moving forward, maybe we can learn a lesson from your country, or perhaps share your experiences of life in a war-torn country.

@Jerry

"...leading the way in spearheading the removal of a dictatorship that oppressed and tortures its citizens. "

Is this a joke?

The US is infamous for setting up petty dictators in countries we want to control.  In Central America, in South America.  The worst struggling countries is Central America are struggling because we set up governments that would protect US business interests.

Have you forgotten the role the US played in overthrowing the duly elected Allende in Chile?  

And we replaced him with a ruthless dictator, Pinochet, who absolute and totally tortured his citizens.

I'm not saying the US is all bad, or that all military actions were bad.  

I am saying that citizens of *every* country need to critically analyze themselves, not just lavish immodest and half-truthful praise.
